Legal_Issue: Misinterpretation of employment requirements under NOC
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's bachelor's degree in Japanese considered relevant to translation as a related discipline
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate error in decision
Legal_Rule: NOC requires a bachelor's degree in translation or a related discipline; visa officers must not impose stricter criteria
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider 'related discipline' as per NOC
Grounds_for_Claim: Incorrect legal interpretation by visa officer
Outcome_on_Merits: Application allowed on merits due to legal error
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Decision found procedurally unfair due to misinterpretation
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, NOC classification system
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged refusal of points for work experience based on narrow degree interpretation
Court_Result: Judicial review granted, referral for reassessment by different officer
Remedy_Requested: Reassessment of application by another visa officer
Outcome: Permanent residence application referred back for reassessment
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review under the Federal Courts Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: NOC requirement for degree in translation or related discipline
Outcome_of_Review: Decision found flawed, remitted for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: National Occupational Classification (NOC) standards for interpreter occupation
